item.title: Implement and throw = error?
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

Lorax:

Yea, I solved it by catching it in the run method, also it’s no good throwing it in the run method because the normal paintComponent’s method run doesn’t throw it, so I can’t override. I just realised that when trying out your idea.

you can’t throw it. You could throw a runtime exception instead. un-check exception but still catchable.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Lorax Lorax
item.description:
@Lorax wrote:

Yea, I solved it by catching it in the run method, also it’s no good throwing it in the run method because when i implement Runnable the run method from Runnable does not throw any exception. (I guess I was tired when I wrote about the paintComponent and stuff).

item.title: Implement and throw = error?
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

classes do not throw exceptions,
methods throw exceptions

the method run() can throw an exception, the class makeStars (which should be MakeStars btw) can not

Read full topic

item.title: Implement and throw = error?
item.dc:creator: @Lorax Lorax
item.description:
@Lorax wrote:

[code]private class makeStars implements Runnable throws InterruptedException {
public void run() {
Random random = new Random();

  for (;;) {
    try {
      Thread.sleep(random.nextInt(4000 - ( getLevel() * 300 )));
      starList.add(new Star());
      repaint();
    } catch (StarHitException e) {
      return;
    }
    
  }
  
}

}
[/code]

why does netbeans say that it expects a { in the first line?
because it doesn’t seem to expect that when I just throw or just implement.

Read full topic
